title: 105_hr4600
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Smoking Prevention Act of 1998" includes a penalty for smokers in group health plans under the Public Health Service Act. The "Common Sense Smoking Prevention Act of 1998" penalizes smokers in group health plans by allowing denial, cancellation, or renewal refusal of benefits for those who refuse smoking testing, and by increasing premiums by 10% for smokers identified by a licensed physician. The "Common Sense Smoking Prevention Act of 1998" penalizes smokers in group health plans by allowing denial, cancellation, or renewal refusal of benefits for those who refuse smoking testing, and by increasing premiums by 10% for smokers identified by a licensed physician. The act defines a family member as a spouse or child of the individual and requires compliance with notice requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Amendments include adding sections 2704 and 2706 to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 713. STANDARD RELATING SMOKERS. In the case of medical care provided under a group health plan or group health insurance coverage, the plan or issuer cannot deny benefits or coverage based on a participant's refusal to undergo smoking testing. However, they can increase premiums by 10% if a licensed physician determines that the participant is a smoker. The term 'family member' in this section refers to a spouse or child of an individual. The requirement of this section is considered a material modification in the terms of the plan, and notice must be provided within 60 days after the first plan year in which the requirement applies. Section 731(c) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 713. Section 732(a) of the Act is also amended. Section 732(a) of the Act (29 U.S.C. 1191a(a)), as amended by Public Law 104-204, is updated to include sections 711 and 713. The table of contents in section 1 of the Act is amended to reflect this change. Section 713 of the Act introduces a standard relating to smokers in individual health insurance, amending Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2706(a) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those for group health plans. Section 2762(b)(2) is amended to include additional sections. Effective dates for the amendments are specified. Effective Dates: The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 1999. The amendment made by subsection (b) applies to health insurance coverage in the individual market on or after that date. For group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, the amendments do not apply before the termination of the agreements or January 1, 1999. The enactment of this Act specifies that any plan amendment made to conform to new requirements shall not terminate a collective bargaining agreement. Additionally, regulations are coordinated to include specific provisions from different acts.
